newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australian authority tenders for two sewage plants.
newsitem.headline: Australian authority tenders for two sewage plants.

text.p: Sydney Water, the New South Wales state-owned water and sewage authority, said on Thursday it has called for expressions of interest to build, own and operate two sewage plants in the greater Sydney region.

Sydney Water managing director Paul Broad said the Picton Regional sewerage scheme would have a capital cost of A$60-70 million, and the Gerringgon-Gerroa sewerage scheme would cost about A$20 million.

Sydney Water also intended to call for expressions of interest in August for contracts to design, construct and operate a tertiary treatment plant at Cronulla to be integrated with the existing plant, Broad said.
The Cronulla contract would have a capital cost of about A$100 million.
Broad said Sydney Water would also tender for the first two projects.

He expected expressions of interest from groups including Australian Water Services, a joint venture between France's Lyonnaise des Eaux and Lend Lease Corp Ltd, and French company Compagnie Generale des Eaux.
Other possible international bidders included Britain's Anglian Water and Thames Water.
"You will get a good field of international players and you will find they will partner local players," he told a briefing.
Broad said a shortlist would be finalised by August, contracts awarded in mid-1998 and the two projects were expected to be completed in 1999.
The move represents the first time a significant part of Sydney's sewerage scheme has been put out to tender.
Sydney Water is Australia's largest water utility with A$12 billion in assets.
